Despite this, the al-Nusra Front and Free Syrian Army factions continued to cooperate in the southern Syrian governorates of [[Quneitra Governorate|Quneitra]] and [[Daraa Governorate|Daraa]].{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/11/20/uk-mideast-crisis-south-idUKKCN0J422U20141120|title=Syrian insurgents attack government-held town near Israel|work=Reuters|accessdate=22 November 2014|date=20 November 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/security/2014/12/jabhat-al-nusra-islamic-state-clash-qalamoun-risks-daraa.html|title=Jabhat al-Nusra, IS clash in Daraa|work=Al Monitor|accessdate=20 December 2014|date=16 December 2014}} ==Background== Before the clashes, there were already tensions between Jabhat al-Nusra and the Syria Revolutionaries Front.{{cite web|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/security/2014/08/syria-idlib-war-jabhat-al-nusra-factions.html#|title=Idlib prepares for war between factions and Jabhat al-Nusra - Al-Monitor: the Pulse of the Middle East|work=Al-Monitor|accessdate=30 October 2014}} 100 members of the latter had been killed by al-Nusra during clashes in July 2014.{{cite web|url=http://aranews.net/2014/07/isil-jabhat-al-nusra-announces-second-islamic-emirate-syria/|title=After ISIL, Jabhat al-Nusra announces Islamic Emirate in Syria|work=ARA News|accessdate=30 October 2014}} After that, Nusra launched the [[2014 Idlib city raid]], which resulted in a failure. They blamed the Syrian Revolutionaries Front for the failure, because, according to al-Nusra, the SRF stabbed them in the back. Then, they launched the offensive. However, according to the [[Syrian Observatory for Human Rights]] (SOHR), the clashes between the two sides already started the day before the raid.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/posts/602538909854451|title=Idleb Province|publisher=|accessdate=30 October 2014}} ==Conflict== ===Zawiya Mountain offensive (October–November 2014)=== The clashes between the two sides erupted on 26 October with conflicting information about the reason. Between 27 and 28 October, the al-Nusra Front attacked the SRF and took over the towns and villages of Balyon, Kesafra, Eblin, Ebdita, Mashon, Maghara and Maghara as well as four of their checkpoints near Maarrat Al-Nu'man. "This has happened before and we came through it. But this time the mobilisation is very large," said a military official in the [[Syria Revolutionaries Front]] (SRF). He added that the SRF had taken 25 al-Nusra fighters prisoner. He also claimed ISIL fighters were reinforcing the Nusra Front in the assault. But the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) said that it was another hardline group, [[Jund al-Aqsa]], that was providing the backup.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/posts/603633533078322|title=SOHR was informed that...|publisher=|accessdate=30 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/10/28/us-mideast-crisis-syria-idlib-idUSKBN0IH1KW20141028|title=Al Qaeda seizes territory from moderate Syrian group|work=Reuters|accessdate=30 October 2014}} On 28 October, the al-Nusra Front also attacked a checkpoint of the [[Hazzm Movement]] in western Aleppo countryside but this attack was repelled and a number of Nusra fighters were reportedly killed. At the same time the Al-Atareb area and the Regiment 46 witnessed a "tension and wait-and-see attitude" after these clashes. Another clash took place between the two parties in the area between Ma’er Debseh and Khan al-Sobol in the Idlib countryside.{{cite web|url=http://www.syriahr.com/archives/33999 |title=اشتباكات بين حركة وحزم وجبهة النصرة في ريف حلب الغربي وريف إدلب |author=Ahmed Marshal |work=المرصد السورى لحقوق الإنسان |accessdate=30 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141031145334/http://www.syriahr.com/archives/33999 |archivedate=October 31, 2014 }} On 29 October, [[Army of Mujahedeen]] took over the Hazzm Movement checkpoints around al-Atarib, while [[Ahl Al-Sham]] was expected to take over the al-Nusra checkpoints in the same area as part of a deal between the rebel groups. Both parties agreed to release all detainees afterwards.{{cite web|url=http://www.syriahr.com/archives/34108 |title=جيش المجاهدين يتسلم حواجز حركة حزم بريف حلب الغربي بعد 24 ساعة من الاشتباك بين حركة حزم وجبهة النصرة |author=Ahmed Marshal |work=المرصد السورى لحقوق الإنسان |accessdate=30 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141101070308/http://www.syriahr.com/archives/34108 |archivedate=November 1, 2014 }} On 30 October, clashes in Khan al-Sibel between the Hazzm Movement against al-Nusra left three fighters dead.{{cite web|url=http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/153479-syria-rebels-qaida-fight-in-restive-northwest|title= Syria Rebels, Qaida Fight in Restive Northwest |publisher= Naharnet|date=31 October 2014}} On 31 October, 15 Islamic battalions formed the "''al-Sohl (peace-keeping) forces''" and sent them to the al-Zawiya mount area, where the al-Nusra Front and the SRF were still fighting, in order to separate the two parties from each other.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2014/10/an-agreement-between-15-islamic-battalions-in-idlib-to-form-forces-to-separate-between-the-fighting-battalions/|title=An agreement between 15 Islamic battalions in Idlib to form forces to separate between the fighting battalions|author=Master|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=14 November 2014}} The 15 battalions included: the [[Army of Mujahedeen]], [[Harakat Nour al-Din al-Zenki|Nour al-Din al-Zanki Islamic Brigades]], [[Sham Legion]], the [[13th Division (Syrian rebel group)|13th Division]], Omar Al-Mukhtar Brigade, the [[Hazzm Movement]], [[Ahrar ash-Sham]], [[Liwa al-Haqq (Idlib, Syria)|Liwa al-Haqq]], Syrian Liberation Front, the al-Awal Brigade, [[Suqour al-Sham Brigade|Suqour al-Sham]], and [[Jaysh al-Islam]].{{cite web|url=http://www.joshualandis.com/blog/al-qaida-jabhat-al-nusra-allied-militias-advance-idlib-whipping-us-vetted-militias/|title=Nusra’s Offensive in Idlib & its Attempt to Destroy Washington’s Allies. November 2014|publisher=Syria Comment|date=4 November 2014|accessdate=6 November 2014}} Meanwhile, fighting raged between the SRF and al-Nusra in the village of Deir Sinbel, with both sides suffering heavy losses. Before reaching Deir Sinbel, al-Nusra had captured a dozen villages in the area.{{cite web|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2014/11/01/245423_in-setback-islamic-state-nusra.html?rh=1|title=US-backed forces in Syria suffer big setback|publisher=|accessdate=14 November 2014}} The next day, al-Nusra forced the SRF to retreat from the village.{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/11/01/us-syria-crisis-nusra-idUSKBN0IL2QT20141101|title=Al Qaeda group seizes bastion of Western-backed rebels in Syria's Idlib region|work=Reuters|accessdate=14 November 2014}} With the fall of Deir Sinbel, Nusra had taken control of most towns and villages on the Zawiya Mountain. This also caused many SRF fighters join the al-Nusra Front.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/posts/605265996248409|title=Idlib province|publisher=|accessdate=14 November 2014}} At the same time, ISIL sent some of its fighters to the contested area (al-Barah, Kensafrah and the eastern countryside of Ma’arret al-Nu’man) to aid al-Nusra in their fight against the SRF,{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2014/11/islamic-state-sends-some-fighters-to-support-al-nusra-front-in-idlib/|title=Islamic State sends some fighters to support al- Nusra Front in Idlib|author=sohranas|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=14 November 2014}} some of whom were involved in the fight for Deir Sinbel. After this, the al-Nusra Front agreed to a proposed cease-fire, starting at 2 o'clock, but demanded that Jamal Maarouf had to appear before a Sharia court within 24 hours after the judge's request.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2014/11/al-nusra-front-agrees-on-proposals-to-stop-fighting/|title=Al- Nusra Front agrees on proposals to stop fighting|author=sohranas|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=14 November 2014}} On 2 November, al-Nusra seized [[Khan al-Sabil|Khan al-Subul]], in the Idlib province, after Hazzm Movement fighters retreated from the town.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2014/11/al-nusra-front-seizes-the-town-of-khal-al-sobol-in-idlib-while-3-regimes-soldiers-killed-an-officer-in-homs/|title=Al- Nusra Front seizes the town of Khal al- Sobol in Idlib, while 3 regime’s soldiers killed an officer in Homs|author=sohranas|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=14 November 2014}} al-Nusra further took control of the villages/towns of [[Maar Shurin]], [[Ma'saran]], [[Dadikh]], [[Kafr Battikh]], and [[Kafr Rumah]] from the Islamist rebels and Hazzm Movement, thus taking over almost the entire Zawiya mountain area.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/11/nusra-front-advances-syria-idlib-2014112142010325171.html|title=Nusra Front advances in Syria's Idlib|author=Al Jazeera and agencies|publisher=|accessdate=14 November 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.syriahr.com/archives/34498 |title=جبهة النصرة تتوسع في ريف إدلب، وتسيطر على قرى وبلدات جديدة |author=Ahmed Marshal |work=المرصد السورى لحقوق الإنسان |accessdate=14 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141104183657/http://www.syriahr.com/archives/34498 |archivedate=November 4, 2014 }} On 3 November, al-Nusra fighters were reportedly gathering in the town of [[Sarmada]] in Idlib province, some 4 miles (6 kilometers) from the Bab al-Hawa border crossing that is held by the Islamic Front. If al-Nusra Front seized the crossing, it would block an important supply line for the Western-backed rebels.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Nov-03/276352-syrian-al-qaida-forces-amass-near-turkey-crossing.ashx#axzz3HeXxMr5L|title=Syrian al-Qaida forces amass near Turkey crossing|publisher=The Daily Star|date=3 November 2014}} By that point, the Hazzm Movement was completely defeated. Hundreds of its members defected or escaped; its cache of American weapons was seized by the al-Nusra Front, and the group's leader and some 50 remaining fighters left the area and headed for Aleppo.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-29902384|title=Syria conflict: Jihadists 'beating America's allies'|publisher=BBC News|date=4 November 2014|accessdate=5 November 2014}} The next day, the Northern Knights Brigades in Aleppo province retreated from the [[Menagh Military Airbase]], burning a [[T-62]] tank, in the face of an al-Nusra advance.{{cite web|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/11/jabhat-al-nusra-idlib-islamic-emirate.html|title=Jabhat al-Nusra eyes Idlib for Islamic emirate - Al-Monitor: the Pulse of the Middle East|work=Al-Monitor|accessdate=23 February 2015}} On 7 November, the [[al-Nusra Front]], with the support of [[Jund al-Aqsa]], seized the villages of [[Safuhin]], [[Fatirah]] and [[Hazarin]] in the southern countryside of Idlib, as well as the village of Flayfel in the Shahshabo Mountain.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2014/11/al-nusra-front-takes-control-over-3-villages-in-idlib/|title=Al- Nusra Front takes control over 3 villages in Idlib|publisher=SOHR|date=7 November 2014}} On 13 November, al-Nusra captured [[al-Rami]], the last village held by the SRF in the mountains.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/SyriaDirect/status/533244273693454336|title=Syria Direct on Twitter|work=Twitter|accessdate=19 January 2015}} ===Further al-Nusra advances (November 2014–March 2015)=== On 29 November, Syrian activist Omar Jassim, said that the al-Nusra Front seized the city of [[al-Rastan]], in the Homs province, and captured a large number of Free Syrian Army fighters after clashes between the two sides, and subsequently established a number of checkpoints in the city.{{cite web|url=http://www.alquds.co.uk/?p=257719|title=جبهة النصرة تسيطر على الرستن ومقتل ثمانية أشخاص في قصف لطائرات النظام على الرقة|publisher=Al Quds|date=29 November 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/news/arabic/2014/11/29/%D8%AA%D8%AC%D8%AF%D8%AF-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D8%B5%D9%81-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B1%D9%82%D8%A9-%D9%88-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%86%D8%B5%D8%B1%D8%A9-%D8%AA%D8%B3%D9%8A%D8%B7%D8%B1-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B1%D8%B3%D8%AA%D9%86|title=تجدد القصف على الرقة و"النصرة" تسيطر على الرستن |publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=29 November 2014}} On 30 November, al-Nusra executed 13 Syrian rebels in Kawkaba, in the south of the Idlib province, after taking the village.{{cite web|url=http://www.annahar.com/article/194075-%D8%AC%D8%A8%D9%87%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%86%D8%B5%D8%B1%D8%A9-%D8%AA%D8%B9%D8%AF%D9%85-13-%D9%85%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%AA%D9%84%D8%A7-%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%B6%D8%A7-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D8%AF%D9%84%D8%A8?id=194075|title="جبهة النصرة" تعدم 13 مقاتلا معارضا في ادلب|publisher=An-Nahar|date=30 November 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2014/11/al-nusra-front-kill-13-fighters-from-al-ansar-brigades-in-idlib/|title=Al- Nusra Front kills 13 fighters from al- Ansar brigades in Idlib|publisher=SOHR|date=30 November 2014}} The same day, al-Nusra stormed the town of Kafr Nabudah, after which SRF and FSA fighters in the town handed over all of their weapons.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/EjmAlrai/status/539146652221964288|title=Al Nusra stormed the town Kafr Nabudah in Hama|publisher=Elijah J. Magnier|date=30 November 2014}} At the end of December 2014, al-Nusra seized another Hazzm Movement post in the Kafar Karmin area of the western countryside of Aleppo.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2014/12/the-nusra-front-seizes-a-post-of-hazem-movement-in-aleppo-and-the-clashes-continues-in-al-mallah-area/|title=The Nusra Front seizes a post of Hazem Movement in Aleppo, and the clashes continues in al- Mallah area|author=sohranas|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=19 January 2015}} On 29 January 2015, al-Nusra expelled the rebels from the Regiment 111 base in Aleppo province.{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/qaeda-group-launches-assault-western-backed-syria-rebels-145357739.html|title=Qaeda group launches assault on Western-backed Syria rebels|date=30 January 2015|work=Yahoo News|accessdate=1 February 2015}} At least four rebel fighters were killed in the fighting at the base.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2015/01/4-members-of-hazem-movement-killed-in-aleppo-and-mortar-shells-kill-5-civilians-in-aleppo/|title=4 members of Hazem Movement killed in Aleppo, and mortar shells kill 5 civilians in aleppo|author=sohranas|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=23 February 2015}} The next day, fighting spread to Idlib province where several small al-Nusra checkpoints were attacked and overrun in the Jabal al-Zawiya area. Clashes also occurred at the rebel-held Regiment 46 base during the previous night.{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/01/30/uk-mideast-crisis-syria-idUKKBN0L312M20150130|title=Syria battle between al Qaeda and Western-backed group spreads|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}} Al-Nusra also captured 11 fighters of the FSA Division 16.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2015/01/the-infantry-division-16-gives-al-nusra-front-a-time-limit-to-release-the-captives/|title=The Infantry Division 16 gives al- Nusra Front a time limit to release all the captives|author=sohranas|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=23 February 2015}} By the end of the day, al-Nusra's ally [[Ahrar ash-Sham]] captured the Bab al-Hawa border crossing with Turkey from the Hazzm Movement after fighting between Hazzm and al-Nusra.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/us-backed-syrian-rebels-are-overrun-pushed-out-turkey-border-crossings-1800712|title=US-Backed Syrian Rebels Are Overrun, Pushed Out Of Turkey Border Crossings|date=30 January 2015|work=International Business Times|accessdate=1 February 2015}} On 16 February, al-Nusra stormed the headquarters of the 7th Brigade (part of the FSA's [[101st Division (Syrian rebel group)|101st Division]]) in the village of Ayn Laroz in the Zawiya Mountain and captured a large cache of weapons after it took control of the FSA's posts. This was the last FSA stronghold in the area.{{cite web|url=http://syriahr.com/en/2015/02/the-nusra-front-storm-the-village-of-ayn-laroz-and-arrest-dozens-of-fighters/|title=The Nusra Front storms the village of Ayn Laroz and arrests dozens of people, including fighters|author=sohranas|work=Syrian Observatory For Human Rights|accessdate=23 February 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/al-qaeda-linked-group-captures-large-supply-weapons-western-backed-rebels/|title=Al-Qaeda linked group captures large supply of weapons from western-backed rebels|author=Leith Fadel|work=Al-Masdar News|accessdate=23 February 2015}} On 25 February, al-Nusra declared war on the Hazzm Movement{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/jabhat-al-nusra-declares-war-harakat-hazzm/|title=Jabhat Al-Nusra Declares All-Out War on Harakat Hazzm|accessdate=26 February 2015}} and two days later attacked the Hazzm-held Base 46, west of Aleppo city. By 1 March, they captured the base,[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-2973331/Dozens-dead-Qaeda-militants-Syria-seize-rebel-base.html Dozens dead as Qaeda militants in Syria seize rebel base] Meznaz, Kafar Nouran, al-Mashtal, the area of al-Mohandsin and Daret Ezzeh. 60 Hazzm and 40 Nusra fighters were killed.[http://www.syriahr.com/en/?p=14055 Fighters in Hazm Movement join Nour al- Din Zenki Movement and al- Ansar Brigade] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160106035848/http://www.syriahr.com/en/?p=14055 |date=January 6, 2016 }} Following the losses, the Hazzm movement dissolved itself, and its remnants joined the [[Levant Front]].[http://www.jamestownsun.com/news/nation-and-world/3690163-us-backed-syria-rebel-group-dissolves-itself-after-losses U.S.-backed Syria rebel group dissolves itself after losses] ==Strategic importance== The recent [[Syrian Army]] victories during the [[2014 Hama offensive]] and the [[Battle of Mork]] left the southern countryside of Idlib vulnerable. The infighting between the al-Nusra Front and the SRF endangered the newly formed frontline in the south of [[Khan Shaykhun]]. With the loss of its bastion in Idlib, the SRF was left with only a presence in southern Syria. Western-backed rebel groups in Syria were coming under growing pressure as government forces continued to advance in the country’s west and south.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/11/syria-moderate-rebels-lose-ground-qaeda-201411110414744368.html|title=Syria 'moderate' rebels lose ground to Qaeda|author=Al Jazeera and agencies|publisher=|accessdate=14 November 2014}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Syrian Civil War}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Al-Nusra Front-Syria Revolutionaries Front conflict}} [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War in 2014]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War in 2015]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving the Free Syrian Army]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving the al-Nusra Front]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] [[Category:Idlib Governorate in the Syrian Civil War]]
